learning_outcomes.description: Evaluate bio-based processes and apply advanced design and optimisation strategies towards a wide range of bioprocess applications.
Interrelate knowledge of cellular metabolism and molecular biology with quantitative approaches for regulating cell function to achieve a desired purpose.
Develop and apply metabolic modelling procedures to analyse metabolic networks.
Interface between metabolic engineering, systems biology and synthetic biology, with an ability to cross-communicate within the bioscience, biotechnology and bioengineering fields.

assessments.due_date: In Class during tutorials for the first 30 minutes. Run in weeks 4,5,6,7 and 10,11,12,13.
assessments.task_description:
This is a closed-book, in-person assessment conducted at the beginning of tutorials (30 minutes each). It evaluates students’ understanding of biological mass balances, metabolic engineering concepts and industry contributions and content covered in lectures. The quizzes will include both theoretical and problem-solving questions.

Format:

In-person quizzes during tutorials. An additional make-up quiz will be available for students unable to attend one quiz.

Assessment Conditions:

Closed-book, individual, in-person.

Weighting:

Only the best 6 quizzes will contribute to the final mark.

Learning Objectives Assessed:

  • Apply biological mass balances to metabolic systems
  • Demonstrate understanding of core metabolic engineering concepts
  • Solve quantitative problems related to metabolic pathways

HURDLE

Students must achieve an average of 50% or higher across their best 6 out of 7 tutorial quizzes to meet this hurdle. Failure to meet this requirement will result in a failing grade for the course, regardless of performance in other assessments.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Quizzes will be completed and submitted during tutorials. For laptop-based tasks, students must ensure their devices are charged and functioning. All work must be completed individually. Any breach of academic integrity, including collusion or use of unauthorised materials, will be treated seriously in accordance with UQ’s Student Integrity and Misconduct policy.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: There will be 7 quizzes in total. Only the best 6 quiz marks will count towards the final grade. A make-up quiz will be held in the final week for students who missed a quiz or wish to improve their mark.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Theoretical questions and calculations associated with the prac. Analysis of the experimental data set obtained. Full details and requirements are on Blackboard.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
15/09/2025 4:00 pm

Students with an approved extension will be given a new submission deadline for the assignment, as agreed upon with the course coordinator.
assessments.task_description:
This individual report is about in silico strain design and metabolic modelling:

Each student will metabolically engineer the strain to maximize production of a particular product using constraint-based methods. The project report should include their coding in Excel or other software.

Refer to Blackboard for full task description. 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
